#Text=3. Facility Inspection Algorithm
#Text=3.1 .
#Text=Overview
#Text=The proposed system automatically inspects structural defects of railway environment .
#Text=Most facilities installed in the tunnel , such as overhead rigid conductors , are used to supply electric power into the train through its pantograph .
#Text=Conventional inspection systems detect all candidates of wears and cracks using single image-based processing methods .
#Text=The conventional image processing-based approach provides an acceptable detection accuracy for a small FoV images .
#Text=However , it is difficult to distinguish whether detected region is a real defect or not if the image contains complicated frequency components or complex background .

#Text=Moreover , single image-based systems cannot detect defects caused by structure ’s shape deformation and loss of components since most overhead lines and supporters consist of durable metal materials unlike tunnel walls .
#Text=To solve these problems , the proposed system inspects structures and facilities related with overhead lines using a pair of images as shown in
#Text=Figure 3
#Text=.
#Text=The image sets are acquired using the line scan camera at the same spots but at different times .
#Text=We assume that the reference image set is acquired before the target image set , and they have no defects such as deformation and loss based on human inspection .
#Text=The target image set is the one to be inspected .
#Text=The main objective of the proposed system is to detect deformed regions for maintenance of overhead conductors by comparing two images acquired at different times .
#Text=We exclude cracks on the tunnel wall as inspect subject in the proposed system since they are simply extracted by single image-based inspection systems .

#Text=The proposed system consists of three functional steps : ( i ) image reconstruction using registration based on phase correlation and image composition , ( ii ) facility detection using deep learning-based object detection , and ( iii ) facility inspection using image comparison approach based on Weber contrast .
#Text=In this section , we describe each step of the proposed system in the following subsections .
#Text=3.2 .
#Text=Image Reconstruction
#Text=Given a pair of reference and target images , the proposed system first reconstructs each image .
#Text=As shown in
#Text=Figure 3
#Text=, positions between corresponding facilities in the same driving section are not initially aligned because of various problems such as different speed and jittering of the camera .
#Text=In addition , some parts of facilities are often divided into two neighboring frames in the image acquisition process .
#Text=The proposed system registers two images using phase correlation .
#Text=More specifically , disparity or motion vector between two images is estimated by computing correlation in the frequency domain .
#Text=It is more efficient to coarsely register two large-scale images than spatial domain-based motion estimation methods because of simple multiplication of fast Fourier transformation ( FFT ) .

#Text=The motion vector obtained by maximizing the phase correlation is defined as ( 1 ) where and respectively represent the i -th frame acquired without temporal synchronization , and and the Fourier and its inverse transformation operations , respectively .
#Text=Superscript ‘ * ’ indicates the conjugate of a complex number and ‘ · ’ a pixel-by-pixel multiplication .
#Text=In the proposed method , we translate by the horizontal motion value to prevent deformation of in which we should inspect facilities .
#Text=The positions of facilities are coarsely aligned by translating using phase correlation as shown in
#Text=Figure 4
#Text=a.
#Text=Once is translated , we lose the left and right parts of the image .
#Text=When we obtain the negative motion value , the translated version of has an empty space in the left-side region .
#Text=The right-side region with the intensity values is naturally lost as shown in
#Text=Figure 4
#Text=a.
#Text=To fill the empty space , the proposed system reconstructs the image by attaching some parts of the neighboring frame as shown in
#Text=Figure 4

#Text=a , b. We then respectively generate the final reconstructed images and by attaching appropriate regions of the neighboring images onto and since the left-side facility of is sometimes lost in the image acquisition process .
#Text=Although some regions are duplicated , we can prevent from skipping the inspection of the regions .
#Text=The lost region in is used when reconstructing neighbor frames at the previous or next inspection stage .
#Text=3.3 .
#Text=Facility Detection Using Convolutional Neural Network
#Text=To automatically inspect railway facilities , we should find out their positions and classify types of them since each type has different risk management standard for a deformed area .
#Text=A simple approach is to define absolute positions of all facilities in advance .
#Text=However , it is inefficient since we should change the facility positions whenever the reference image set is replaced by new ones .
